description: Inherited from Middle English gab, gabbe, from Old Norse gabb (“jest, mockery”) (whence also Old French gab, gap (“mockery, derision, scorn”)). Cognate with Icelandic gabb (“hoax”).

entries.meaning: One of the open-forked ends of rods controlling reversing in early steam engines.

description: From Middle English gabben, from Old English gabban (“to scoff, mock, delude, jest”) and Old Norse gabba (“to mock, make sport of”); both from Proto-Germanic *gabbōną (“to mock, jest”), from Proto-Indo-European *ghabh- (“to be split, be forked, gape”). Cognate with Scots gab (“to mock, prate”), North Frisian gabben (“to jest, sport”), Middle Dutch gabben (“to mock”), Middle Low German gabben (“to jest, have fun”).

verbs.description: gab (third-person singular simple present gabs, present participle gabbing, simple past and past participle gabbed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To jest; to tell lies in jest; exaggerate; lie.
(intransitive) To talk or chatter a lot, usually on trivial subjects.
(transitive, obsolete) To speak or tell falsely.
